docs.lead_paragraph: In December 2000, as the Clinton administration was leaving office, we released the first-ever national standards for protecting the privacy of Americans' medical records. Those rules were designed to protect the privacy of information about patients and consumers that doctors, hospitals, health plans and health insurers keep. It was a staggeringly complex task, one that consumed much of my last three years as secretary of health and human services.
docs.abstract: Donna E Shalala Op-Ed article explains medical privacy provisions proposed by Clinton administration and now under final review; notes that Pres Bush, strong supporter of medical privacy, accepted almost all of proposals (M)
docs.snippet: In December 2000, as the Clinton administration was leaving office, we released the first-ever national standards for protecting the privacy of Americans' medical records. Those rules were designed to protect the privacy of information about patients...

docs.lead_paragraph: A huge supply of smallpox vaccine frozen for the last 44 years appears to be as potent and effective as newer vaccine produced for the nation's pharmaceutical stockpile, federal officials and drug company executives said today. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, confirmed that the government would receive a donation of about 85 million doses of the smallpox vaccine from Aventis Pasteur, a major vaccine maker.

headline.main: Frozen Smallpox Vaccine Is Still Potent, Officials Say
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BIOTERRORISM THREAT

docs.abstract: Federal health officials say huge supply of smalpox vaccine frozen for last 44 years appears to be as potent and effective as newer vaccine produced for nation's pharmaceutical stockpile; Sec Tommy Thompson confirms donation of 85 million doses from Aventis Pasteur; photo with company chief executive Richard Markham (M)
docs.snippet: A huge supply of smallpox vaccine frozen for the last 44 years appears to be as potent and effective as newer vaccine produced for the nation's pharmaceutical stockpile, federal officials and drug company executives said today.    Tommy G. Thompson,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pfizer, the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that the Justice Department was investigating two years of pricing of Lipitor, a drug used to treat high cholesterol. The investigation is looking into whether grants made to certain health plans and pharmacy benefit managers should be characterized as rebates, Pfizer said in its annual report. Rebates would entitle the government to a better discount under Medicaid price rules, the company said. Pfizer, based in New York, said it was cooperating with the investigation on 1999 and 2000 pricing by Warner-Lambert, which Pfizer bought in June 2000. Lipitor is Pfizer's biggest-selling drug.

headline.main: PFIZER SAYS U.S. IS INVESTIGATING PRICING OF A DRUG

docs.abstract: Pfizer Inc says Justice Department is investigating two years of pricing of Lipitor, drug used to treat high cholesterol; investigation is looking into whether grants made to certain health plans and pharmacy benefit managers should be characterized as rebates; company says rebates would entitle government to better discount under Medicaid price rules; Lipitor is Pfizer's best-selling drug (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 11. Now Playing ''ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS,'' starring Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).

docs.lead_paragraph: HCA, the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, announced an agreement today to repay the federal government $250 million to settle an ongoing dispute over fraudulent Medicare and Medicaid billing. The resolution is subject to approval by the Department of Justice and a final agreement.

headline.main: Hospital Chain in Settlement With U.S.

docs.abstract: HCA, nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, announces agreement to repay federal government $250 million to settle ongoing dispute over fraudulent Medicare and Medicaid billing; resolution is subject to approval by Justice Department and final agreement; HCA pleaded guilty two years ago to defrauding government health care programs and agreed to pay more than $840 million in criminal fines, civil penalties and damages; agreement announced settles outstanding appeals and more than 2,600 cost reports HCA sent to government programs from 1993 to 2001, some of which government has not yet audited (S)
